text: here I sit outside our headquarters
trench in the Sun all should be nice and
peaceful and pretty what it actually is
is beyond description
trenches ammunition tools caps etc etc
everywhere poor fellows shot dead -
lying in all directions mm war Diaries
one and a half million documents these
were the fodder for authors and
researchers now for the first time the
day-by-day accounts of life at the front
are available at the click of a mouse
leftenant welcome the fourth battalion
Middlesex regiment the order to retire
was at last given in such a way as to
cause alarm these are the methodical
musings of a giant army details of
attacks of supplies of football matches
behind the lines of casualties laid out
on official military forms and stored
away for a hundred years the CEO sent a
message to the trench companies to
retire as best they could in the face of
a very hot fire but as we had already
discovered the Germans could not shoot
and their losses were only about 12 men
between them I think their release of
the war Diaries is immensely importance
there the raw material of our
understanding the First World War
they're not the stuff that you get from
a book that you can go along someone's
written for you it's what was written at
the time it's the experience day by day
as written up by the unit's adjutant
that says casualties what they did where
they were it's an immensely valuable
resource
the names carved onto our local war
memorials are the most obvious reminders
of the First World War but all of us
will have a direct connection with
somebody who served in this conflict the
hope is that these Diaries released into
the public domain will give more and
more people the opportunity to follow a
personal trail and by doing that
detective work we can help historians
map the war for future generations these
are the web pages of operation war diary
a way of feeding back our information
and filling the gaps we'll never have
that detail we'll never have that
information and so we really do need
people to help us and by doing this
they're making as well as having a rich
and engaging experience and a
contact with these documents they are
they are contributing to history they're
contributing to the legacy of the
centenary that data is a legacy from the
centenary is something which historians
will be able to use for decades and
generations to come in the old
photographs countless unnamed soldiers
gaze at the camera lens their fate
already sealed the personal comments
attached to the official reports were
often the last words they wrote
everywhere the same hard grim pitiless
sign of battle and war ghastly
absolutely ghastly and whoever was in
the wrong in this matter which brought
this war to be is deserving of more than
he can ever get in this world Robert
Hall BBC News
